column4: aeleon-> your server is behind your client? am kind lost on your description
edward_-> it is a tuff one, there are tutorials you can find via google..
and when I try to look at my router's settings from my client, i can see it clearly.
your openvpn tunnenl is between which and which?
uhh? it's between an xp client here in the UK and an ubuntu server which is one of four behind a router. the other three are my family's pcs.
So I 192.168.1.1'd in my browser, and it got me into my router's settings at home, so I figured I could open ports. but, like I said, when I use, say, utorrent's port checker, it says they'r closed.
forward ports.
I'm sitting on my client with access to my server and i want to forward ports.
I want to be able to stream music.
and I don't want to use the port my server's listening on.
what? i want it streamable online.
ehh, yes and no. i want to run a shoutcast from my client while VPN'd to my server.
well, like i said, when i told my router to forward the port and then checked from my client to see it was open, it said it was closed.
because all my music's on my client.
certainly those can be transferred over to your ubuntu server right?
no, to be honest. there's too much of it.
why can i log into it successfully, then? and why does my server's ip come up when I look up my external ip?
it sees my one at home. it has to, because i'm at school.
no. when my vpn is on, all my traffic routes through my vpn.
thats what i want to establish
sorry if I didn't say that earlier.
i have to leave for a few, need to pick up stuff, be back in 20 mins
aight, thanks.
